I always liked Disney's "The Jungle Book" as a kid, and this modern live-action adaptation is a fairly solid remake of that version of the story. It is a pretty exciting visual experience, but I do think it lacks some of the simple charm of the animated version from the 60s. The best bits come from Bill Murray as Baloo, but the kid playing Mowgli is a pretty good lead. I like seeing a kid's movie that isn't afraid to go dark in the right amount of doses in this day and age...when things can either be too dark and gritty for kids or too bubbly and light...I think this found a decent balance.

In a world full of CGI, I would normally destroy a film for basing their entire film on computer visuals instead of a great story. The fact that we all know and are well familiar with this all time classic leaves little to be expanded on, as far as plot and story goes that is. But, if it's one thing that this updated live CGI action film did justice to this cherished classic was the visuals gave this story a whole new look and life to it. The Jungle Book not only impresses but it surpasses all its CGI brethren of films. From the look of the jungle to the facial animations of the animals, it's mesmerizing to say the least. The breathtaking visuals add a visceral look to it's all non-threatening cartoon animation counterparts with their loud vicious roars, low growls, and threatening animalistic sounds. The sound is truly spectacular immersing you in the depths of the jungle making you feel every step in the mud hearing rain create percussion sounds as it lands on the bed rock. What brings these animals to life is their amazing voice actors giving A+ performances. This film may not bring much to the forefront of story telling but it's visuals will you talking and pleasantly satisfied for months to come until the next Disney live action film arrives. I'm looking at you Beauty and the Beast. (8/10)

I wasn't a fan of Disney remaking their classics in live action until I saw the best movie of 2016, The Jungle Book. This film simply blew away. I can't think of any other words to describe my experience watching this movie. I refuse to say this movie is perfect, because there has never been nor will there ever be a perfect movie, but I have absolutely zero complaints to make about this film. 

I think it's safe to say that I highly recommend The Jungle Book.

Great retelling of the classic, bringing elements of the Lion King and Avatar somehow together to make a gorgeous, engrossing, yet simplistic story of a boy ("man-cub") trying to find his place in the jungle. A nice surprise was Christopher Walken as the giant orangutan King Louie.

If you are looking for one of those films that demonstrates new techniques in visual imagery, than Disney's "Jungle Book" remake is for you. It is on that same list that sets "Avatar" and "Gravity" from the dozens of other films using (or mis-using) CGI. And visually, "Jungle Book" impresses. However, if you're looking for any kind of magic regarding story and script surprises, you will be less successful. Watching this gave me strong vibes of Disney's "Dinosaur" back in 2000, which boasted (at the time) revolutionary animation, but was sorely lacking on all other fronts. 

Let's start off by analyzing the favorable:  the animation will flabbergast you. The creatures are so lifelike, I was under the impression that artists had superimposed CG lips and eyes over real animal footage. By comparison, they make the animals in "Narnia" look like utter garbage. But the truly awe-inspiring feat pulled off by "Jungle Book" was not in the wolves, bears, and large wild cats; no, the real stunner was the fully-photorealistic and completely believable environments these animals lived in. Trees, foliage undergrowth, rocks, streams, hilltops, and temples, every background looked like something pulled out of a Discovery Channel show. All of it looked believable.
 
With that said, I do wonder why Disney decided to go to obscene lengths to animate all backgrounds, as the finished film did not utilize the technology to its fullest. For the most part, "Jungle Book" played like a live action film with not as many carefully-planned camera swoops and pans as I would have expected. The Kaa sequence, as an example, was a waste of potential; while the Walt Disney classic had the snake demonstrate its awesome length by coiling, turning, grabbing Mowgli and playing with its food, this Kaa was so static and unmoving it might as well have been accomplished through matte painting. The entire thing may have felt "grounded" in part because of the way filmmakers chose to bring Mowgli to life... 

... And this leads me into the first major complaint I had with this film. Mowgli. I will give young Neel Sethi a break because he's a kid and I won't dwell on the fact that he was no Haley Joel Osment, but I will criticize filmmakers for not truly pushing the boundaries in animation by attempting to pull off a fully-lifelike CG character. In short: they cut corners. They didn't even try to go the extra mile in the one area of CG that needs the most innovation. Boo to Jon Favreau and team for being so paranoid of the "uncanny valley" they didn't even attempt to innovate. If they had just tried, I would have given them a full star more in my rating. I will give them credit for seamlessly blending in Neel Sethi into every background, but I do think using a live actor greatly limited the scope and vision of the overall film. 

Now, for the deluge of criticism...
The story was a complete mess. The script was an even greater mess. I have criticized Walt Disney's 1967 animated film for its lack of narrative direction, as the story seemed to be a series of unrelated antics tying one scene to the next, story obstacles to prevent Mowgli from reaching the man village. Here, the events are even more random and convoluted. Kaa appears and then she exits the story forever. King Louie appears and then he exits the story forever. The elephant herd appears and then leaves the story forever (without saying a word, too!) At least the animated classic integrated these characters and had them return. For example, the animated film had several scenes with Kaa, and a very memorable and tense encounter between Shere Khan and Kaa. Not here. In the animated film, there were important interactions between Bagheera and the elephant pack. Not here. I would have forgiven these antics if they could have at least ended the story. In this version, nothing gets resolved, as far as Mowgli learning to be a man. (I assume he will be enslaved to con-bear Baloo in honey-capers for the rest of his life? What a waste of human potential.) Mowgli does not even reach man village, which defies the entire point of the plot! Wasn't the symbolic image of Mowgli wielding and controlling the "red flower" supposed to denote that he alone possessed powers and ingenuity no animal could possess? The whole film ended flatter than a popped tire. I left feeling as unsatisfied as watching part one of a two-part cliffhanger (ahem, "Deathly Hallows: Part I.") 

There were so many things that I disliked about the story. The Kaa scene especially was   annoying. First off, I was puzzled why Disney did a gender swap; I hope it was not because Disney realized there was only one female character in the film, and (like always) they need to have at least one evil female in movies nowadays. But even worse than gender-swapping was how Kaa hypnotized Mowgli; apparently someone in the story department thought it would be intelligent to shoe-horn a flashback sequence here-and-now, completely with mysterious Scarlett Johansson narration to remind us of Galadrial in "Lord of the Rings." Honestly, did we need to see Mowgli's past? And even if we did, couldn't somebody pick a better moment for the flashback? Another horrible aspect was the way Shere Khan was handled. I got the impression that instead of being frightened by fire, he was drawn to it, because he willingly and stupidly climbed a dead tree in the middle of a forest fire without having the foresight that a dead tree might snap. For that matter, how did Mowgli get off that same tree during the same forest fire? How was Mowgli able to run with the torch of fire all the way from the man village to the wolf den, unless the forest was only 50 feet long? And top top it off, I wish everyone would quit referring to fire as "red flower." I'm pretty sure that in Kipling's original, "red flower" referred to the physical attributes of a campfire, not a raging forest fire. If I was Shere Kahn witnessing half the forest burn down, I would not exclaim: "Look at that red flower!" Instead, my reaction would be more primal: "Ahhh!!! Red hot terror!!!!!!!!!!!" A  red flower? No. Just no. 

When it all boils down, the only sequence I truly enjoyed was King Louie. It was funny, it was scary, it had an awesome remix of the classic "I Wanna Be Like You." Here, filmmakers used CG to its fullest potential, in this case turning King Louie into a 15-foot-tall ape of incredible strength,(the song cleverly incorporates new lyrics saying that he is, in fact, a gigantopithicus. Bonus points for that.) I also sense a dark humor in screenwriters when the monkey temple crushed King Louie, rendering the last remaining gigantopithicus extinct. A nice touch. The entire sequence was loaded with a level of fun and innovation the entire movie should have had, but did not. What should have been laughs throughout was constipated dialogue.

In the end, while I dig the animation, this new "Jungle Book" was too butt-kissy to the Walt Disney classic to stand on its own two feet. And yet, it was not dark and realistic enough to be a faithful adaption of the Rudyard Kipling original. It resides in no man's land. Honestly, Rotten Tomatoes, 95% fresh?

I had only one true issue with Jon Favreau's Jungle Book, and while it does seem like sort of an unfair one, it's also a pretty huge one.

For months before I got the chance to see this remake, I heard non-stop about what a great actor the kid playing Mowgli was, how photorealistic all the animals were, and how you would never be able to guess that the backgrounds were all actually sound stages that had been animated over. Well I just watched The Jungle Book, and I found all three of those compliments to be patently untrue. That might sound like three issues, but in reality they all boil down to the same one thing, suspension of disbelief. Or more accurately, the lack of it. From the word go, there wasn't s moment that I found myself being continuously drawn out of the story because of one of those reasons (usually the look of the creatures). I was not once able to fully engage, and though I recognise that from a plot point of view, this version was even better than the 1967 one, I still found myself constantly aggravated by the harsh meshing of Mowgli against the world around him.

My reaction towards The Jungle Book reminds me very much of Zootopia, another Disney movie.   The latter film has a near perfect percentage rating on Rotten Tomatoes.  It has only four negative reviews out of 220 tallied on the site.  People praised it as one of Disney's best animated movies ever.  And, when I saw it, honestly, I was a little underwhelmed.  Don't misunderstand me, Zootopia is a hell of a movie.  But it's nowhere near close to Disney's best when it comes to animated movies.  Not even close.  Not saying that this one had the same reception, it's got 95% reviews on RT, but a lot of people were indeed raving about the movie.  And, again, much like Zootopia, I was left a little befuddled by that.  This is nothing more than a good movie with fantastic CGi work.  But, to me, it's nothing more than just a good movie.  I gotta give them props, though, because the movie is darker than one might expect a Disney movie to be, but there was just something missing.  There's many issues I have with the film.  But, to me, the most important one of all is the fact that Neel Sethi, the kid who plays Mowgli, isn't a very good actor.  That's just the truth of the matter.  It wouldn't have been much of a problem if Neel had been cast as a secondary character, but Mowgli is the central character of the story and one of the very few humans in the actual film.  So the fact that they chose him is mind-boggling when I'm sure a ton of other kids auditioned.  If he was the best of them all, then I really don't wanna see the worst of the bunch.  There's literally nothing behind his eyes.  He's just a kid, reciting lines.  He doesn't embody the character whatsoever, he doesn't add life or personality to the character.  There's some scenes where he's fine, but there's some scenes where he's just terrible.  For example, the climactic scene of the film when the wolf pack, Baloo, Bagheera and Mowgli finally decided to fight back against Shere Khan and everyone else rushes Shere Khan.  Mowgli, before rushing at Shere Khan, does this battle yell to, somehow, try to appear intimidating and it was just absolutely awful.  And it wasn't meant to be comedic or anything like that, this is the climax of the film while there's a giant wildfire going on in the background.  So talk about embarrassing.  This is supposed to be the moment when Mowgli stops trying to run away and face his fears head on and that yell was just awful.  I'm surprised they actually let it even make the final cut.  I would have just cut it out, no questions asked.  Neel's delivery on some lines is just so wooden and bad.  It's seriously surprising how this kid actually got the role.  And I realize I seem to be bagging on him too much, but he's the lead and the story is completely centered around him.  So he's the one that I'm gonna focus on the most out of anybody, as he's the only human in the film.  So, yea, this kid was awful.  Secondly, the narrative of the film absolutely did not engage me in any way whatsoever.  Like none, you're just sort of thrown in this universe with minimal introduction and you're somehow supposed to be invested in it?  Eh, doesn't work like that.  There's no real attempt at world building outside of the introduction and some little bits and pieces.  And then to top that off, you have the 'emotional' connection between Mowgli, Baloo and Bagheera.  And I put that in quotations because there was no actual connection between them, just the film telling you that they were close.  Yet again, there's no actual development between these three characters, they don't really build those relationships well at all.  The movie just tells you that these three are super close and that Baloo and Bagheera are willing to sacrifice their lives to help this kid, but you just never see it.  Again, the movie just tells you and expects you to believe them.  And, apparently, a lot of people bought it.  I think this all comes back to the casting of Neel as Mowgli.  It really does.  Every other character in the film is CG animated, so it all comes down on Mowgli to sell that connection he felt to the wolf pack that he'd want to go back to face Shere Khan and to Baloo and Bagheera.  I seem to really be ragging on this movie, huh?  There's two musical numbers in the film and both of them are horrifyingly out of place.  Bare Necessities is in there, I'm assuming, at the behest of Disney.  Maybe I'm wrong, but it just feels like one of their moves.  The other musical number, featuring King Louie, is far more elaborate and even more out of place than the Bare Necessities one.  Like what was the actual point of it all.  Why were there two musical numbers randomly placed in the movie?  Particularly when, as I mentioned, the tone of the film is far more serious and darker than the original film.  I can kinda see justifying having Bare Necessities in there, but the King Louie one is just unacceptable on all levels.  This one is far more nitpicky, but I still felt that it hurt the movie.  They even replay King Louie's song over the credits and it would've made more sense for it to have been placed there as opposed to in the actual movie, where its placement is unjustifiable.  I think that's about it as far as the negatives.  The positives are, as mentioned, the CGi is just outstanding.  Like, literally, it's some of the best I've ever seen, in terms of realism, even down to small movements, and just the amount of detail put into them.  It is something to behold to say the least.  The voice acting is top-notch, all around, everyone is great.  And they would have to be seeing how bad Neel Sethi was.  The movie is also, surprisingly, action-packed.  There's a lot of set-piece moments that are actually really cool and really well done.  So no complaints on that front.  You know, as a whole, in spite of the flaws taking up, like 70% of the review (maybe even more), I'd still say that this is, by and large, a pretty solid movie.  Is it better than the original Jungle Book?  Probably, I haven't seen the animated version in ages.  But this movie is still rampant with flaws that can't be overlooked.  This is a solid rental, at best.  It's just got too many negatives to be anything more than that.

It's really hard to not completely gush over "The Jungle Book" because it was just that incredible of a film.  Whether it is the amazingly gorgeous visuals or the excellent cast or the special effects that are absolutely incredible at making photorealistic environments and animals, the film really delivers on a technical level.  Furthermore, the film provides a very enthralling adaptation of the book and delivers it with excitement, humor and heart.  There was nothing about this movie that I didn't enjoy and I absolutely loved it.  "The Jungle Book" is just a magical and very entertaining movie.

This has the bare necessities to adequately retell the Jungle Book story but the wit and charm of the animated classic are certainly missing. While the CGI quality is generally solid and it boasts couple entertaining scenes, this modern adaptation has a fair amount of elements which just don't fit. 

First you have the voice acting. Actors appeared to be largely picked on their current celebrity status instead of suitability, a common occurrence in today's animations. The supposedly terrifying tiger, Shere Khan, is hard to take seriously when he has the Londoner accent of Idris Elba. I'm surprised he did not threaten Mowgli by saying "You want some, you want some do ya?". Admittedly he grows into the role but the casting definitely could have been better. Christopher Walken as King Louis gives the impression that he wasn't going to tolerate any monkey business since he plays the orangutan like a mafia boss. This is fine and actually worked in conveying greater intimidation up until he breaks into the famous "I wanna be like you" song. It just did not compliment the atmosphere that had been created while Walken's old fragile voice struggled to hit some of the higher notes. This leads onto another point that this and the 'bear necessities' song were shoe-horned in. I thought the style of this movie lends itself to a music-free narrative, however they felt obliged to honour the popular soundtrack of the Disney original. Understandable but not a successful choice in my opinion. Lastly, we have Mowgli's interaction with the animals. The actor looked the part but, and I feel harsh criticising a child, he could have prospered from more direction. It became too obvious sometimes that the animals were not there and he was interacting with a green screen. I'm not saying it is easy but it made it difficult to become fully immersed from an audience point of view.

Maybe a cruel evaluation of a movie which probably satisfies the intended role of good family entertainment. The story still holds up and the action scenes with Shere Khan and King Louis are impressive. In my book, modern adaptations or remakes will always suffer from comparisons to the original and on this occasion it is clear the 1967 animation continues to be King of the Jungle (Book).

The Jungle Book transports you into a beautiful world filled with incredible set-pieces. If director Jon Favreau's intent was to have each location create a shift in mood, he wildly succeeds. The rocky stomping grounds of the wolfpack creates an air of lightheartedness. Once Mowgli sets foot on the watering hole or trudges through the open plains of high-grass, you instantly get a feeling of uneasiness, like something bad is about to happen. Go further into the jungle depths and it will make your skin crawl as you await the dangers that are seemingly lurking around every corner. All of these set-pieces are not only distinct, but succeed independently of animal interaction. I was nervous for young Mowgli's safety inside the Monkey Temple long before King Louie showed up.

The characters make up the other half of the movie's successful equation. Each animal, originally done in their own right, dominate their respective scenes while advancing the story. Even the smallest parts, like the giant squirrel played by Sam Raimi, are completely unique and help flesh out the jungle world. My favorite character, Ikki the porcupine (played by Garry Shandling) had a minute role but made me smile the entire time he was on screen.

Mowgli the "man-cub" has been raised in the wild by a family of wolves. While the wild is all he has ever known, his parents know that eventually he is going to have to insert himself into human life. Bagheera the panther, Mowgli's mentor, decides now is as good a time as ever to take Mowgli to human society as the man-cub suddenly finds himself being hunted by Shere Kan the vicious tiger. While the film is plenty enjoyable, it definitely isn't without its faults.

Disney's movies, Pixar in particular, are particularly good at stirring up emotion within the audience but there were moments in The Jungle Book that missed the mark for me. There is one particular pivotal moment in the film that occurs that should have been a very moving moment, but it happens...and nothing. I'm not sure if emotional conveyance is the proper terminology, but if it is, this film could have used more of it.

I was also a bit thrown off by the motive of the antagonist Shere Khan. Shere Khan wants Mowgli gone from the jungle because he is a man-cub and men only bring danger and destruction to the life around them. I get that part. What I didn't understand, however (spoiler alert?), is why Shere Khan continued to be so persistent after Mowgli tried to leave the wild. Why not, I don't know, just let it go? Most animals, when threatened, move on once the threat has seemingly been eliminated. While I did appreciate Khan's bad-assness, I wasn't quite sold on his necessity of pursuit.

Finally, I want to take a moment to bring up Neel Sethi's performance as Mowgli. Though nothing stellar by any means, I thought it was a decent performance. I actually liken his performance to that of Jake Lloyd when he played young Anakin in Star Wars: Episode I--The Phantom Menace. I find it a bit funny that, while Sethi's performance was lauded, critics came down extremely hard on Lloyd's acting. At the end of the day, they're kids and they shouldn't be expected to have the same chops as Sean Connery or Liam Neeson. Lloyd wasn't the problem in The Phantom Menace just as Sethi's ok performance in The Jungle Book doesn't make the movie any less enjoyable.

It's hard to believe that it was 49 years ago when Disney released an animated interpretation of Rudyard Kipling's collection of stories known as The Jungle Book. I was a young tyke at the time and I loved the film so much that my parents must have regretted buying me the soundtrack album afterwards. I'm sure they grew very tired of hearing "The Bare Necessities" and the other memorable songs on the LP being played over and over again. (How was I supposed to know, or care, about the whole backroom drama surrounding "I Wan'na Be Like You"?*)

As I was watching the film again the other night, I was struck by how simple it was. The story plays out like eight or so (I wasn't counting) Flintstones-like episodes about the panther, Bagheera (voiced by Sebastian Cabot), and his attempts to get young Mowgli to leave the jungle and return to the man-village. The film's mood was very light and references to pop culture at the time were woven throughout the storyline. Both Baloo and King Louie were obvious lovers of Dixieland/New Orleans jazz, which is not surprising given who voiced these characters (Phil Harris and Louis Prima, respectively). As the sun set on the jungle and Mowgli went off with his new love, we were assured that everyone would live happily ever after. Although the 1967 version of THE JUNGLE BOOK doesn't rank as one of Disney's best efforts, it does hold up to time although perhaps more so for very young viewers. Today's nine-year-olds might find the animation laughingly primitive or the story too simplistic.

The 2016 version of THE JUNGLE BOOK is a whole different affair. Although director Jon Favreau (CHEF) used the 1967 film as his inspiration, he created a Disney film for today's audiences. Mowgli and the gang are all back, though this man-cub is played by real-life, 12-year-old actor Neel Sethi starring in his feature-film debut. Both the animals and the jungle were created on computer screens in downtown Los Angeles, we're told in the closing credits, and they are so lifelike it's often hard to believe that they're not the real thing. This interpretation of Kipling's short stories is slightly different too. There are no Beatle-esque vultures here, and the elephants play a less prominent role. Shere Khan (voiced by Idris Elba) has a larger role and is much more menacing than his 1967 counterpart. As a result, the film has a darker tone than its predecessor and may not be ideal viewing for very young children. Favreau's TJB is also more violent - one animal dies and the jungle catches fire due to carelessness (no doubt an environmental message coming from drought-stricken California where forest fires are now becoming a regular occurrence). But, as an homage to the 1967 film, Favreau included three of its classic songs, two of which are sung during the film and the other during the closing credits. Unfortunately, while this was a noble - even romantic - gesture, it doesn't work and the two songs seem jarringly out of place. Favreau, or perhaps even Disney's execs, may have thought the story was getting too dark and they wanted to lighten up the mood with some bouncy tunes but they were completely unnecessary. Today's audiences are sadly used to darkness and violence.

Surprisingly, or perhaps Favreau was keeping close to the 1967 screenplay, King Louie appears in this film too. (The simian was never a character in Kipling's original works.) However, rather than being an orangutan again, a species that is not native to India, Favreau's King Louie (voiced by Christopher Walken) is a Gigantopithecus, an extinct species of great ape. Favreau and Walken also draw upon contemporary pop culture by having Louie sound like Marlon Brando's Col. Kurtz from the film, APOCALYPSE NOW! I doubt young viewers would see the connection but anyone who is old enough to remember the original film will get it.

Sethi's performance is nothing short of golden, and not just because he's the only human in the film. He had to learn parkour so that it would appear that he could bound over rocks and swing from vines with the greatest of ease. Ben Kingsley (the voice of Bagheera) lends the perfect amount of gravitas to the role, and Bill Murray (the voice of Baloo) is ideal as the carefree bear. In a break from the 1967 film which had an all-male but one cast, Favreau cast Scarlett Johansson as the voice of the s-s-s-s-seductive python, Ka. She, too, makes the most of her all-too-brief encounter with Mowgli. Christopher Walken is the weak link among the voice actors in the film. Once we see King Louie in all his hirsute glory, Walken's characterisation of him changes from army man-gone-native to New Jersey mobster. Perhaps if he could carry a tune, his rendition of "I Wan'na Be Like You" wouldn't have been so annoying.

Even with its missteps though, the 2016 THE JUNGLE BOOK is still a winner and will be remembered as a Disney classic. Go see it on the big screen and be sure to sit through all the credits. (Keep your ears out for the late Garry Shandling who provided the voice for Ikki the porcupine.)

* King Louie was a character created for the 1967 film, and was written with jazz legend Louis Armstrong in mind to be the character's voice. Walt Disney, however, was worried that King Louie would be seen as a racist depiction of black people, a concern made even more apparent when Armstrong would have to sing the line, "An ape like me can learn to be human too". Armstrong was ditched and jazz musician Louis Prima was brought on board to voice the character.

Man's Red Flower Rules Them All. Disney's 2016 live-action remake of "The Jungle Book" is a fabulous piece of storytelling and family fun.  The story was very well written, and the film was brilliantly made and directed.  The voice acting was superbly casted, and I thought this movie was better than the original Animated film from 1967.  But Parents take heed; this is not for little one's.  I heard too many children under 6 crying (50+ screaming unhappy children who were not babies) in several "intense/dark" spots throughout the film.  (this movie's PG means 6+).  Outside of this, I think it will be a surefire family classic for decades to come.  The best part is that they left 2 of the Sherman Brothers' classic songs which lightened up the film and kept it from being too dark to enjoy.  4.3/5 stars.   Theater-worthy and very enjoyable.

The 1967 animated film to me is still one of Disney's best of the "classic era". This is not just nostalgia talking, quite a few childhood favourites have not held up, but 'The Jungle Book' is an example of one that has.

Expectations were mixed for seeing this film. The trailer looked great, the voice cast is filled with enormous talent and the featurette was fascinating. It was just that, relating it to the other Disney live action adaptations, whether it was going to be one example of a re-boot that looked stunning, was well-written and performed, respected its original source material(s) and added its fresh spin, like 'Cinderella, or a well-made film with enough other decent elements to make it watchable but also one lacking in soul and charm, like 'Alice in Wonderland'.

Fortunately, 'The Jungle Book' is an even stronger example of the former, and is one of Jon Favreau's best films along with 'Iron Man'. Fans of the animation will love recognising the familiar characters and scenes and it was also really nice to see more of Rudyard Kipling's writing and story telling here, the ending being closer to that of the animated film. 'The Jungle Book' is wonderful on its own merits too, just like the Disney animated film was, which was a poor adaptation of the book but worked so well as a film on its own that it didn't matter.

Criticisms for the film are very few. The first criticism is that Kaa's scene and screen-time is far too short, a great character like Kaa deserves far more than a mere five minutes or so. And it is a shame because it is a very suspenseful and hypnotic scene with some of the film's most striking visuals, and the deceptively maternal story teller approach was beautifully written and delivered. Regrettably, the other criticism was "I Wanna Be Like You". While one of the highlights of the animated film, and one of Disney's most iconic moments, because the scene is darker and King Louie more intimidating (in size and manner), also because it comes out of nowhere, the light-hearted fun of the song that worked so brilliantly before just doesn't fit here (if Christopher Walken really did desperately want to sing the song, it didn't show in his singing because he sounded uninterested and hesitant).

On the other hand, the film looks amazing. The rich, expansive cinematography is some of the best of the year so far and the scenery and settings are so vividly detailed and colourful, that reading that it was shot entirely in a warehouse was a shock. The rendering of the animals are staggeringly realistic, especially Shere Khan, Bagheera and the monkeys. Favreau directs with a keen eye for detail and spectacle, yet doesn't forget the drama, cast or the storytelling once. John Debney's music score is full of energy, atmosphere, warm orchestration and vibrant emotion, its referencing of familiar themes feeling nostalgic and affectionate rather than cheap. As for the songs in the film, although "I Wanna Be Like You" was a disappointment "Bear Necessities" fitted right in and was as good-natured and easy-going as one can hope and "Trust in Me" is worth listening to if you stay for the closing credits, Scarlett Johansson with her low-register, smoky yet sensual tone does a surprisingly good job with the song.

'The Jungle Book's' script is very funny (Baloo getting the funniest lines, and some of them were hilarious) without being childish or simplistic while also easy to understand and thought-provoking, there is a good amount of depth too without being too dark or sugary sweet. The story moves quickly and is constantly enthralling, one thing it does better than the animated version is expanding on motivations and making characters more interesting (as great a villain as Shere Khan is in the animated film, his motivation to me seemed clearer here). The climax is dramatically satisfying and darkly tense.

A great job is done with the characters also. They're not complex, but they are likable and interesting, are very true in personality to their animated counterparts and all serve a point in the storytelling, some like Shere Khan and the wolves expanded upon. It was easy to identify with Mowgli, Baloo is a breath of fresh air and to me a great villain is one that one can totally see why the villain is hated or feared but one can also understand their point of view, which is the case with Shere Khan (this is true of the animated film too, but as Shere Khan has more of a back story here it came through stronger to me). The cast were a talented one to begin with and their talents absolutely shine through. Newcomer Neel Sethi does very credibly as Mowgli, it is incredibly hard to react against nothing and apart from a few naturally stiff moments to begin with he handles all the different emotional elements very well. The superbly chosen vocal cast are even better.

Bill Murray was born for Baloo (sounding far more engaged than as Garfield), his relaxed but witty voice-work matching the character's easy-going, good-natured personality. Idris Elba effectively puts dread into one's heart as Shere Khan, he's silky, regal, charismatic and genuinely menacing, though George Sanders brought over the suavity and oiliness more. Ben Kingsley is a stern yet sympathetic Bagheera, and Christopher Walken, in a characterisation that is like a mix of mobster boss, Colonel Kurtz and Walken's own mannerisms, makes King Louie intimidating but also entertaining. Scarlett Johansson's voice work for Kaa is eerily sensual, Giancarlo Esposito is a dignified Akeela and Lupita Nyong'o's Raksha is movingly compassionate.

In conclusion, a truly great film. Works very well as a live-action re-boot and works even more as a film in general. An epic visually stunning adventure, told with fun, heart and depth. 9/10 Bethany Cox

The classic story comes to life once again -- in this eye-popping, live-action CGI-flick. 

What a ride! Just the realistic animation alone is a wow-factor! It was hard to differentiate between the real-on-set objects and the computer generated ones -- that's how CGI is supposed to be used. It's a new and modern take on this classic story, with very similar moments from its source material. Still; very different due to its realism. It got a great development of its story -- with great pacing, action, & many classic Disney-traits like morality, what's life, who's worth more -- and how it is to be different. It even got some interesting perspectives on humanity & the constant hunt for power. It's a truly touching story -- even emotional, with all the happiness circulating around the well visualized characters. I must say -- I did not expect a so captivating film. But wow -- funny and well-fitted character-traits to these beloved individuals is a wonder! They interact in a very natural way with the environment and other characters. Our main "Mowgli", got this personal dilemma -- reflecting where to go in his life -- should I be myself, or fit in society. The film perfectly illustrates how people can affect your opinion -- is Disney trying to be the parent of movies? To summarize; 'The Jungle Book' is a stunning film for youths as adults -- it's so much more than a CGI adventure. Yes; it might not take a very different path from the original film and its story, and it's sometimes a bit too predictable. Another flaw is that I wanted even more inside to the main character -- not only about everything around him, but more about his inside and personality. Everybody out there might not consider it as a "very eventful film". But I think it's a groundbreaker! A remake? Yes. But that totally surpass its source material.

If there's any more proof there aren't any new ideas in Hollywood, it's the fact that beloved animated classics are being remade as live-action films. Sometimes this works, but more often than not, the ploy to attract those nostalgic feelings from the audience fails, thus leaving the viewer with the sense that their childhood is ruined. I'm generally pretty hesitant of these types of films, mainly because part of me doesn't want to admit that the original films sometimes weren't that great. That being said, the latest in these adaptations, The Jungle Book (2016) certainly surprised me.

Unlike some films like Maleficent (2014), which takes a different point of view from the main story of Sleeping Beauty (1959), and more like Cinderella (2015), which covers the same material as its predecessor, Cinderella (1950), The Jungle Book takes the main ideas from Rudyard Kipling's book, via the animated interpretation of The Jungle Book (1967) and brings the adaptation to near perfection. While The Jungle Book's classically animated predecessor certainly had its moments, a lot of its appeal fell to obvious popular culture references (like the Beatles as vultures), and a number of catchy and flashy song-and-dance routines. As a result, I can't honestly remember what the plot of the original film was trying to convey. This was why I was quite impressed with director Jon Favreau's adaptation: the plot was direct and made sense, while also highlighting man's ability to create useful (as well as deadly) tools. It was clear how Mowgli (Neel Sethi) needed to adapt to his strengths to survive in the jungle instead of just hanging around with his animal friends. Also, the clear distinction of the connection between him and Shere Khan (Idris Elba) created a much-needed tension to the story.

Some will recall that The Jungle Book has already been made as a live-action film with The Jungle Book (1994). However, advances in computer-generated imagery over the years have made the ability to create talking animals a mind-numbingly realistic endeavor. The voice acting cast for this version was pretty spot on, and the pacing was fantastic. What's more, there still were snippets of songs and subtle pop culture references (my favorite being the cowbell in King Louie's (Christopher Walken) lair), but they didn't distract from the flow of the film.

A superior film to its classically animated predecessor, 5.0 stars out of 5.

Jungle Book is a well made remake that succeeds in delivering a slightly different story, capitalizing on state-of-the-art CGI and laudable performances to suit the whole family.

When I first watched the trailer, I had real goosebumps when I heard Bare Necessities playing in the background. The nostalgia and euphony of the tune urged me to see the film without a pounding heart. After nearly 5 months I can finally take a close look at this remake. I am a big fan of the 1967 version, which features one of the best sets of songs ever put to the big screen. This 2016 is somehow a much darker, serious film, with more scares and ponderous themes. Throughout most of the screen time, while marveling at the breathtaking scenery and astoundingly realistic CGI (breakthrough performance on the computer's part), I was occasionally bothered by how the plot and scripts deviated from what I expected, and the lack of warmth and humor I enjoyed when rewatching the 1967 musical. The third act is well done, nevertheless, and along with the incredible CGI so as Neel Sethi's extraordinary performance as Mowgli forming the backbone of this remake. Jungle Book is a well made remake that succeeds in delivering a slightly different story, capitalizing on state-of-the-art CGI to suit well for family audience. (Too scary and dark for a kids film, too generic for higher level audiences)

Man, the CGI alone is worth the ticket price (in my case download time). Scenes could have been awkward if the technology had not reach this level, and Mowgli's performance is very worth praising because he expressed and acted naturally even though the characters were not there. 

Yet, I am somehow less satisfied with the film than I thought I should be. Supposedly comedic scenes were somehow dramatized and were given darker turns, and sometimes they feel hollow and disappointing. Elephants scenes are an example. Not only did the elephants not talk, they didn't attain the sarcastic humor that prevails in the 1967 version. Shere Khan was more violent and evil, thus losing the witty sense of humor, and so did Kaa. Another thing is that the relationship between Mowgli and Baloo was not quite as intimate as the first film. Yes, both characters might not be animated this time, but still a weird decision to have Baloo befriending the man-cub just for honey. Baloo's apparent sacrifice at the end was also omitted. As a result, "Bare Necessities" scene was not as memorable as I thought of, and that's cuz their bond was not well developed yet!

I could go on and pick out more stuff that I disliked during viewing, such as how the film ruined "I Wanna Be Like You" by having a big ape throwing fruits everywhere while monkeys squeaked at the background. The scene should be like how the end-credits depicted (King Louie dancing around in his palace). However, I won't go into that much criticism because its a good film. The CGI's amazing. I love how they gave the wolves more screentime and significance, since they are barely developed in 1967 version. Vultures are cut off, good. The third act is also something I never thought would happen in Jungle Book, providing a deeper message and a more thrilling climax than the predecessor. At the end of the day I won't say I am fully satisfied, but yet I'll say I am decently entertained by the CGI and the overall tone of the story. Besides, is there anything better than listening to "Bare Necessities", "Trust in Me" once more with a little modern mix? Priceless.

THE JUNGLE BOOK is a lousy effort that does no justice to the beloved 1967 animated classic that it has adapted. While there are a few small improvements ( a better environment and more polishing) the film's a mess with barely any coherence and horrendous pacing, the voice cast is good but not enough to save the film (Sethi is unbearable at times). I expected better from Favreau since he directed ELF and IRON MAN and already had high hopes for this adaptation but was sorely disappointed. Sparkly CGI was used as an excuse for decent storytelling and depth. The additions to the story were unnecessary ( keep in mind this is adapting the 1967 Jungle Book animated film). The score was average at best but the songs, though whimsical in the original are manhandled here. The 2016 version of THE JUNGLE BOOK is a atrocious mess that fails to capture the magic of Walt Disney's classic film. I'd give THE JUNGLE BOOK a 1/10.

I had very mild expectations for the film, and it turned out to be the total opposite of what I was expecting: I thought it would be a slow character movie- it was a pretty energetic/well paced movie... I thought it would be a cheesy special effect movie- the effects (talking animals) were well done and not a distraction when watching... Thought it would be annoying sweet film- but it was a decent conflict.

Not bad by Disney live action standards, but it's certainly living on nostalgia. The problems with this film are mostly due to the filmmakers trying to pay too much homage to the original Disney cartoon.

"The Jungle Book" may have some of the most captivating visual effects ever put to film, and a cast of A-List celebrities, but when photorealism takes precedence over any semblance of a relatable plot, and the actors sound like they would rather be anywhere else but in the recording booth, it's hard to see your film as anything but a shallow, uninvolved remake of a beloved classic.

"Remake" is not usually a good word. "Live-action adaptation", when the source material is a cartoon, is a risky endeavor that sometimes works and sometimes flops hard. A film wherein the only actor is a child, supported only by the voices of more notable names, is a hard sell. Talking animals in a live-action remake movie is an even harder sell. Yet The Jungle Book rises above these uncertain odds and turns out a surprisingly solid piece of entertainment.

Full review: http://reelrambling.blogspot.com/2016/07/the-jungle-book.html

I hated the original (1968) animated version,this movie turned that around quickly,i loved this movie let's start off with some pros,Neel Stehi as Mowgli good for a child actor talking to CG creatures,Idris Elba as the viscous Shere Khan,Ben Kingsley as the wise black panther,very good use of CGI,better than Allegiant,fun chase sequences with Shere khan and Mowgli,my favorite Bill Murray as Baloo,one flaw,Scarlet Johansson as Kaa,give her more purpose than just to hypnotize,also a big flaw Christopher Walken as a fat hairy Orangutang,that was stupid,I loved it either way though

The original Jungle Book was an animated Disney classic and when I heard they were remaking it I thought that it wasn't a good idea. However, when I saw the movie, I was impressed at how good it was. Disney pulled together an all star cast with Bill Murray, Scarlet Johansen, Ben Kingsley, and Christopher Walken. Even Neel Sethi was decent as Mowgli. The effects in this movie were gorgeous and all fit the tone of each scene. Each character in the film was strong and unique. The settings felt real and the music was great. One of my only complaints for this movie is that some scenes I really liked ended fast. Also Mowgli is kind of annoying sometimes. Overall, The Jungle Book is a movie remake with personality and heart.

The jungle book is directed by Jon Favreau and stars Neel Sethi, Bill Murray, Ben Kingsley, Idris Elba, Luptia Nyong'o, and Christopher Walken. First off, I was pretty excited for this movie Because so far Disney has been doing a great job with these live action films and also i love Jon Favreau as a director. Walking out of this movie, I Loved it!! Everyone a part of this movie did an excellent job from acting,Cgi, directing, everything. The blend of real and cgi was done so well, all thanks to the fantastic director Jon Favreau. Every film he does, it gets better and better. This is his best film yet. Now Neel Sethi, this was his first ever movie and for that I thought he did a great job. There were scenes I didn't think  he would be able to do but I was totally wrong. Everyone did great, especially Idris Elba as the villain. Bill Murray is fantastic as always. Personally the person who blew me away was Christopher Walken. He was just amazing. Overall The jungle book is another fantastic movie by Disney and Jon Favreau is only getting better as a director. Definitely needs to be seen in a theater and I do recommend seeing it in 3D. Kids and adults will have lots of fun.
THE BEST JUNGLE BOOK MOVIE BY FAR!!! PERFECTLY AMAZINGLY DONE!

I was really impressed with this movie. Not just the technical aspects, which were so well executed, but the story as well. The CGI was incredibly impressive. They managed to honor the original Disney movie through some judicious choices of songs and visuals but also make it its own new and different story as well. I found it to be an improvement on what came before.
Visually stunning and well-executed classic.
I never seen the cartoon. But this movie was fantastic!!!

One of those live-action Disney films that's a mixed bag. One of its problems was that the music was often too loud; it was hard to hear the characters speaking. Also, I thought Scarlett Johansson was wasted in her one scene as Kaa. But on the bright side, the pros outweigh the cons. The CGI was stunning, the story was epic, and I thought Neel Sethi did a good job as Mowgli.

Disney presents a life action of the classic film The Jungle Book. The film is not a complete remake, and features quite a few differences from the original animated classic. The movie is visually stunning and some of the shots done as Mowgli traverses the forest are spectacular. The story changes used from the original I did not particularly care for or agree with. I thought Kingsley was a perfect Bagheera, but did not think that Murray's personality best fit the goofy Baloo. Kaa's presence was drastically cut in comparison to the first film, but done rather well. The King Louie scene was probably the most different take, but the film in general replaced goofiness from the original with charm, or darkness. The CGI for the wolves and other characters was fantastic, and made for some heart warming scenes. The movie is still well worth watching, but I enjoyed the songs and tone of the first film more.

The original adaptation of Disney's 'The Jungle Book' was a very sweet film. This charm persists in this more mature adaptation and leads to a film that arguably has an even broader appeal, while living up to modern cinema standards well without falling to pitfalls.

While not groundbreaking in any regard, it's simply an incredibly pleasant film to watch and with excellent craftsmanship all around. One of the best examples I can think of for a children's film that most adults would also enjoy, unless severely opposed to the subject etc.
Loved it! Great movie for the entire family!!

This film was fun and just a joy to see how much detail was used in creating each character.  The voice casting was brilliant and Neel Sethi holds his own in a film that was probably filmed almost entirely in front of a green screen. The film is not perfect.  Perhaps it's because the cgi animals appear to be more cgi than anticipated (mainly the background animal extras). Still I would consider this a great cinematic achievement.

I'm dreadfully disappointed in this remake. It's not the graphics that bothers me, it's the feeling while watching . It was just... overwhelmingly underwhelming. The only emotion I got out of the whole movie was the moment between Mowgli and his wolf mother. The rest just felt boring and empty. I won't lie, I'm likely being biased with this review since I absolutely love the 1967 animated version of the film. But despite it being animated, it has more realistic emotion and feel to it than the 2016 live action/CGI version. Not my cup of tea.

I hesitate to say that it improved upon it's predecessors, considering that the original was my favorite of all the classic Disney films, and it's success kept Disney in the game (Walt Disney passed away during the production of the original Jungle Book).  But I loved the new version.  They changed the story enough to make it new, e.g., Mowgli growing up as a wolf, but kept enough of the bear necessities to hearken back to the original.  The acting and voice acting was superb, the story was engaging, and the special effects - even in this day of CGI wonders - was executed to perfection.  I can't imagine special effects getting better until the time comes when we watch holograms and sniff olfactory chemicals in the cinemas of the future.  I suppose I wish they had included a few more things I loved from the original, but I enjoyed the new material, too.  5/5

This does a great job of maintaining balance between wonder and terror that will have a strong impact on kids. Baloo remains a fun character that will probably be a favorite of most, while Kaa and Shere Khan could easily give younger children nightmares. The meshing of live action and CG is impressive and will probably be the standard for what's inevitably the next wave of live-action recreations of animated classics.
I was really looking forward to this movie as soon as I heard about it. And it didn't let me down one little bit. I highly recommend it to anyone and everyone.

While visually stunning throughout and successfully one-upping its original, The Jungle Book can't help but be made less immersive by its star studded voice cast, which does far more damage to it than good. With Johansen as a hissing snake, Walken as a mafioso primate and especially with Bill Murray as a lazy bear, it seems the animals of The Jungle Book are all far better suited for the man village than its protagonist.

The Jungle Book was easily a Disney favorite as a child. How many times did I watch the cartoon? Beyond count. Then in 1994 came the first live action adaptation with Sam Neil and Cary Elwes, which was a solid take on the classic book. Now Disney takes another stab at making a live action adaptation of The Jungle Book, and at a point in time where Disney is rebooting all their classic cartoons to live action. Not a very likable time in my opinion. Outside of Pixar, Disney continues to keep originality on long term hold. This continuation to reboot and recycle the same material in Hollywood annoys me. The story is set, and it is pretty much the same story we've all grown to know and love. Now comes the part where a lot of recent films have failed. Seeing that the filmmakers actually gave a damn about telling the story as well as making the experience fun, rather than phoning in the project due to it's already established success. Jon Favreau is the director of this live action adaptation. With a unique filmography ranging from Made to Elf to Zathura to Iron Man to Chef, his take on the Rudyard Kipling book is both genuine and wonderful to watch. He completely homers here with The Jungle Book, which for me quickly became the first film since Mad Max: Fury Road where I was struck with complete awe and wonder. 
The Jungle Book is a great journey from start to finish. It's not just another kids movie filled with over-the-top goofy corny G-rated gags. Nor is it another kids movie catering to an audience of just kids. When it's being funny the film is funny, when it's thrilling the film is exciting, when it's sad it even got an emotional response from me. With an A-list cast featuring great names like, Ben Kingsley, Bill Murray, Christopher Walken, Idris Elba, and Lupita Nyong'o, the film is carried by one single live action performance from a 13 year-old actor named Neel Sethi. The pressure of Neel's performance as Mowglu was crucial to The Jungle Book, cause every other actor only had to lend their voice. The result, you could not ask for a better performance from a 13 year old, like the one Neel gives as Mowgli. He carries the whole film without needing a single adult actor to step in for help, even though there are some great scenes from both Bill Murray and Christopher Walken. Both steal the spotlight, but only for a little bit. Another key character to the film is the jungle itself. The film's jungle is structured heavily with CGI, and yet the film does not lose it's balance to it's effects. The visuals are certainly jaw-dropping and breathtaking, but they do remain a backdrop for the characters and the story. But what a beautiful backdrop the visual effects are in The Jungle Book. To be impressed by visual effects is becoming more and more of a rare thing these days. The Jungle Book's visuals did more than impress, they dazzled me with child-like glee.    
To watch Favreau's Jungle Book, was almost like being catapulted back through time and into a child-like state of mind where you find yourself laughing, smiling, and being  at the life's simplest things. Not since Babe has there been this great of a live action movie featuring talking animals. Jon Favreau knows exactly how to reach kid in all of us.

Before I begin, I know what you're going to ask, and yes, they kept the Bear Necessities and I wanna be like you songs. There were a lot of considerable similarities and differences to the original actually. Similar: the characters, general plot, and songs. Different: certain events of the plot, new sub-plots, the closer attention to themes, and the overall quality of the film. This one was better.

This is a reboot of the original 1967 cartoon version of the film, and Director Favreau displayed his supreme directing skills in balancing the existing events of the original and giving older audiences some nostalgia and making the film more contemporary and making the characters and areas of plot a lot more three dimensional. This skill matches that of J.J. Abrams in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Without any spoilers, there are little changes in the plot that cause big ripple effects to what is the final product which may make some fans upset, but I found these changes to be welcoming and even required for this film to be a success. I will further explore each of these differences throughout the review. Needless to say, Favreau switched the film up in a way that made it deep, fulfilling, and entertaining for all audiences despite it being labelled as a children's movie.

I did have some issues with the plot however- namely Shere Khan's role. In the beginning, Shere Khan, the ruthless bad guy tiger who kills animals all the time, shows jungle etiquette by giving Mowgli a head start to get out of the jungle before he kills him. How nice of you evil tiger. After one half-hearted attempt at snatching Mowgli, he devises a plan to take over the jungle (no spoilers, but something happens here) and, assuming word gets across to Mowgli, Mowgli will then come to Shere Khan and then he will kill him. So the element of a chase movie that was present in the '67 version was more lacking this time round. The tiger's patience gave Mowgli plenty of time to make new friends and have a couple sub-adventures. Even though for the larger portion of the film Khan didn't do much, he was a very scary and menacing villain in both destructive capabilities and in his manner; a worthy villain for the intelligent man-cub Mowgli. Different to 1967, he had motivation for going after Mowgli which made him a better and more intriguing character. His tale was very much a tale of revenge. I was scared of him! Parents: don't be surprised if your young one is scared too.

Favreau brought the film quality, and a great cast to go with it! Even though most of these guys where voices, you could see characteristics of their face in their character's face- especially Walken's character, which I found very interesting. The cast included Neel Sethi, Scarlett Johansson, Bill Murray, Idris Elba, Ben Kingsley, Christopher Walken, Lupita Nyong'o, and Giancarlo Esposito. All of their voices suited their characters perfectly. I loved re-exploring the chemistry and relationship between Mowgli and big bear Baloo. Each character brought with them their own tone when they were on-screen whether it was menacing, mysterious, lighthearted, tense, protective, or loving, this film was an emotional rollercoaster. This was actor Neel Sethi's first performance and he performed brilliantly, portraying Mowgli in a way that did justice to the character. I look forward to more of his work.

Genres were extensive due to each character's contribution. There was action, adventure, comedy, drama, family, fantasy, and thriller. It blended each of these with great finesse and the movie had great balance. Thriller was a bold addition, but just made the film all the more satisfying. Our setting was, once again, the jungle. Themes played a big part in this movie including belonging, acceptance, sacrifice, morals, revenge, undeviating love, peace, prejudice, family, journey, and teamwork. While Walt Disney focussed on telling a fun story that lets the imagination explore, Favreau concentrated on recreating this world while making the film a deeper one to be enjoyed by a wider variety of audiences. The themes created valuable morals which young audiences can learn from. Win win.

The special effects were flawless, there wasn't one instance where I doubted that a character wasn't real. There were a couple of risks made in this one, but they all worked out fine. The script was also impeccable, there were some valuable gems in it. For those who have seen the film, I especially enjoyed the story told by Sheer Khan to the baby wolves, and the law of the jungle.

The running time was longer than the average for a family film, so young audiences attention spans may wander, but I was thoroughly engaged throughout. Although there were a lot of sequences part of the 'adventure', they weren't necessarily central to the story. This may bore some. The editing kept a fair ratio of screen time to Mowgli's adventure and what was happening meanwhile at the heart of the jungle. In terms of box office performance, I don't think it will get as much as it should get mainly due to the minimal marketing and potentially other films drowning it out.

The Jungle Book doesn't have heaps it could work on, but I would say that the monkey king sequence could've been cut out, there wasn't much contribution to the story, it was mainly just killing time which didn't need to be there in the first place. Maybe you could work on the element of the chase more.

To Conclude, this is one of the first family films that I can safely say adults will enjoy watching due to their relationship with the original and its excellent quality. It's got something for everyone. Favreau was successful in conveying the intended morals and I can say that The Jungle Book has a HIGH rewatchability level. It's not surprising that this film is excellent with Disney's almost flawless track record, and I'm looking forward to Disney's 2016 films such as Alice Through the Looking Glass, Finding Dory, and the BFG.
The Jungle Book is a great live-action movie, it's visually stunning, great storyline, and also has a good message, but still can't ignore about the violence in the movie.

Disney arrives with a truly visionary and amazing film this 2016, this time a live action retelling of the classic Rudyard Kipling story, which they first adapted in 1967 as an animated film, though this film is more of an inspiration, going in its own direction, with a slightly darker spin and approach.

The film follows Mowgli, who seeks out a journey, aided by various animals, while the threatening and evil tiger Shere Khan attempts to kill him.

The film is a visual wonder and great treat, with a terrific cast. Newcomer Neel Sethi depicts Mowgli and is the only human actor in the film, since many of the actors are computer generated creations. Sethi does an amazing job, since as an actor, he has nothing to work with. He wonderfully commands the screen, making you believe in his journey, while remarkably depicting Mowgli as a strong-minded and strong-willed child. Throughout the entire film, he is able to command the film, while he also has great chemistry with the actors voicing the animals. He's not only believable, but delivers a performance of realism and believability. In all honesty, he truly deserves a nomination for Best Actor for managing to work with absolutely nothing on the film. The voice cast is impeccable and brilliantly picked. Ben Kingsley voices Bagheera as a general, with a true sense of command and knowledge, while he also shows compassion for Mowgli. Bill Murray is wonderful as Baloo, bringing the right amount comedy, while also appearing serious in scenes. Christopher Walken is terrific as King Louie, who is given a slightly larger appearance, as a secondary villain. Walken is menacing when he needs to be and friendly at other times. Scarlett Johansson is exceptional as Kaa, depicting the character with a more serious approach, instead of a comedic foil, which the animated film had done. The real standout in the voice cast, though, is Idris Elba, who voices Shere Khan. Elba is absolutely magnificent in the role, appearing splendidly evil, while allowing the character to be highly menacing, even off screen. Elba, as Shere Khan, has got to be one of the greatest Disney villains, since Jeremy Irons as Scar in The Lion King, Keith David as Dr. Facilier in The Princess and the Frog and Richard White as Gaston in Beauty and the Beast. Lupita Nyong'o and Giancarlo Esposito are also perfectly cast as the wolves that watch over Mowgli.

Jon Favreau masterfully directs this film, crafting a film that is not only original, but also full of magic and wonder. Favreau, who is probably mostly well-known to this generation for bringing Iron Man to life, is an amazing choice for this film and also seems like the best choice to deliver a new tale of The Jungle Book. Favreau crafts a film with real heart and relatable characters, successfully having us follow a young child on journey of self-discovery, while encountering danger at every turn. With the help of Favreau, as well as screenwriter Justin Marks, you not only relate with Mowgli, but also the countless characters he encounters on his journey. Marks, especially, manages to craft an original film as screenwriter that feels like something for a whole new generation. Bill Pope's cinematography is astounding, wonderfully switching color for every scene and location that Mowgli encounters. At times light, other times stark and dark, the lighting and camera angles are perfectly developed and handled, while this film also works well in 3D, primarily IMAX 3D. Watching it in 3D you feel like you are part of the film and action, while seeing it on a giant screen like IMAX further adds to the action and adventure in the Indian jungle and landscape. John Debney's score has a mystical feel to it, at times incorporating elements of the score from the 1967 film in a smart and genius manner. The songs The Bare Necessities, Trust In Me and I Wan'na Be Like You are interwoven brilliantly into the plot. While the film mainly relies on speaking, instead of singing, elements of the songs appear in speech, while the songs appear in full through the end credits. This approach perfectly goes along with the film, since switching to a musical for a short amount of time would seem awkward and out of style for a film that is approached in a more serious and darker manner.

The real treat of this film are the visual effects, which brilliantly and realistically bring the animals. While watching the film, I never thought that the animals were CGI, since they appear so life like, which one of the film's many successes. This is similar to Life of Pi, where the animals, mainly the tiger, were CGI, but in a very realistic approach. The animals in this film walk and sit like actual animals, proving that visual effects are constantly evolving and changing. I do believe that this will gain the film an Academy Award for Best Visual Effects, which it truly deserves.

The end result is a film full of magic, while also proving that Disney can still deliver films of originality, with real heart, magic and wonder. While not a direct remake of the 1967 film, and in my opinion very superior, the film is more of a love letter, while also acting as a film for a whole new generation of film goers. Bravo! Bravo indeed!

Rudyard Kipling's story appears pretty autobiographical. He grew up in India playing with Indians, but always different, and he never grew up in Britain. So is Mowgli's struggle in the animal kingdom. The loyalty of his adopted family and his eventual acceptance of his humanity. Understanding why he is feared, but also offers things other animals cannot.

Yet all of the sudden the experience gets very real and extremely dangerous, at that point we any of us have the strength, courage and desire to do what he did? Would we be smart enough at such a young age to overcome all the obstacles being presented us the manner that he did or would we falter and cave in to the fear? This is a movie for all of the kids out there over 6. From 6-106, this movie has something for all of us. Now grab ahold of your seat and let's swing into the fascinating world of mowgli and the Jungle book. Action=5, acting=5, story=4.5. Cgi=5 all in all I give this movie 5 stars. Fantastic live action adaptation of the Jungle Book. Based on the animated The Jungle Book (1967) this version spins it slightly different and meanwhile still pays homage to the original. Mowgli (Neel Sethi) is a young boy who's been raised by Raksha (Lupita Nyong'o) a wolf along with the rest of her pack. Mowgli was brought to the wolf clan by the panther Bagheera (Ben Kingsley). When a massive drought hits the land the fearsome tiger Shere Khan (Idris Elba) returns and discovers the secret of Mowgli. Shere Khan gives the wolfs an ultimatum telling them when the water returns they must give the boy to him. Mowgli feeling like he's a problem to everyone decides to leave with Bagheera and be with his own people. On the way Mowgli comes across many different animals including the hypnotic snake Kaa (Scarlett Johansson), the goofy Baloo (Bill Murray) and an orangutan named King Louie (Christopher Walken) that has an agenda of his own. The movie has a lot of heart and you really feel for Mowgli and his situation. He's a stranger in a very strange world. Always trying to fit in, but never realizing that he's his own person. The film looks absolutely beautiful. Although, a lot of it is shot with CG it looks. The voice actors give life to the life like animals and everything blends together quite well. Small gripes could be the movie runs maybe about ten minutes too long (how many chase scenes do we need?), but the pacing outside of that is pretty well done. Overall, give it a look if you haven't checked it out!

I would say any further attempt to recreate another adaptation of Rudyard Kipling's eponymous classics The Jungle Book series is close to suicidal. Another film made to capture the hearts of both young and adult, with talking animals, creating the magical bond between a boy and a bear, and obviously extreme ineludible lengths of CGI dependency, not an easy task. We have had many versions produced in the past, some rather successful especially Disney's 1967 animated film version, and we've seen a variety of Mowglis as well, from Jason Scott Lee (1994) to Brandon Baker (1998). Nevertheless the trailer for Jon Favreau's version of The Jungle Book, the fourth and latest edition by Disney, was enthralling enough to bring me to the theatres. Still doubtful though about the storyline (forgive my skepticism, the screenwriter is after all Justin Marks who gave us the marvelous Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li in 2009) I knew I had to watch it in IMAX 3D to at least come out visually entertained. The verdict? Favreau's reimagining of Kipling's dense world of the wilderness is nothing less of spectacular, the screen is bursting with exuberant colors and movements, and watching the anthropomorphic animals going about in their adventures is surprisingly absorbing. Twitter is already calling it "The Revenant" for kids, as it brings the children tale into a darker level, with some thrilling scenes which can be quite overwhelming for younger audience.
Staying close to the 1967 animation storyline, it tells the story of orphaned Mowgli (Neel Sethi) who is found by panther Bagheera (Ben Kingsley) and raised in the wilderness by a pack of wolves led by Akela (Giancarlo Esposito), along with Raksha (Lupita Nyong'o) who cared for him like one of her own cubs. Peppy but docile, Mowgli soaks in all life lessons taught by his mentors and guardians, and yearns to grow up to be just like the wolves in his pack. His childhood is however abruptly shaken when a nefarious tiger Shere Khan (Idris Elba) visits and demands that Mowgli be turned over to him for an unsettled vengeance from the past. Reluctantly, the orphan decides to leave Raksha and the rest of his family, whilst Bagheera concludes further that it is in fact time for Mowgli to leave the jungle altogether and join his own species, pivoting a series of both enlightening and treacherous adventures including meeting Baloo (Bill Murray) the friendly bear, witty and blithe in spirit, Kaa (Scarlett Johansson) the seductive serpent, and King Louie (Christopher Walken) the ape who seeks ultimate power in the animal kingdom.
Entrancing, Favreau's Jungle Book is a visual achievement. The handsome lush Indian landscapes with the clever combination of realistic and fantastical elements provide one of the most interesting, photorealistic all-digital climate to any films we have come across. With ten year-old Sethi being the only live-actor role and the entire story filmed in a studio in LA, Favreau has managed to re-create the beloved classic with a muscle, where his usual mastery in action sequences are put to efficient use, and at the same time coming off emotionally moving. I like the way Mowgli's humanity (and his "man tricks") which inevitably draws him away from his animal families and home, is used as the central theme of the story, but eventually becoming his ultimate weapon to win the battle and find his way "home". Much is put into work to make sure that the animals talk and move in the most realistic manner. You can almost "see" the actors when the animals emote, especially for Shere Khan, Baloo and Bagheera. And for me, it was Sethi's endearing portrayal of the man-cub that stole my heart. A perfect casting choice. "I think it's time to update the story and the themes a little bit for this generation," Favreau shared when explaining the importance of using CGI the right way. Indeed he pulled it off, one example of CGI put to good use. So good, that both Favreau and screenwriter Marks are already in talks with Disney to return for Jungle Book 2.

Ok. Why one star? 1)Not for little kids. Violence and death enter the realm of what was a Disney classic with little or no reason for it. 2)Beautifully done animals that aren't quite real in some way-shape-or form. It is hard to put my finger on just what is wrong with them.  All l can say is they were too perfect. Like rosy cheeked kids starving on an island. It just wasn't - right. King Kong as an orangutan? I'm sorry but to me that was dumb. Mowgli? The kid was fantastic! Loved his acting. But the rest? My wife fell asleep several times and she was the one who really wanted to go see the film. I think if the director had just transported the animated version to real life (as per the OTHER Jungle Book movie Disney made) that they would have had a real hit on their hands. The kid steals the show.  Maybe that is what was wrong - the animals were trying too hard to steal the show? I don't know.  All I can say is - if you put the first Narnia next to this movie and watched them both - I am sure you would understand where I am coming from.  Narnia - The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe - is perfectly done.  Everything fits together perfectly, all of the animatronics is flawless, the CGI is flawless and it all works. This - it just doesn't. There is just something wrong with it. That's all I can say.

Another entry for the recent live action remakes of classic Disney animated films, The Jungle Book is a spectacle for the eye from underrated director Jon Favreau. While I did find newcomer Neel Sethi's take on Mowgli slightly annoying, and a painful rendition of "I Wanna Be Like You" from Christopher Walken; the outstanding CGI and excellent voice acting stopped this film from being a disaster.

A close safe remake of the original and as such there was nothing original to the story. But if you accept that you can sit back and just enjoy what is a beautiful film.  It would have been nice if the committee in their board room had let someone do a Wicked style side story. But they voted to keep the songs short and limited and not break a working formula. There was a lot of acting and musical talent behind this film and it was leashed and you can feel it. This was about easy money and justifying budgets. The CGI is seamless and the only thing that breaks it is when you realise they have captured the actors faces in the characters. This is striking and with King Louie haunting. It is done so well and keeps with the films beautiful realistic style. The many accountants and lawyers behind this only held the movie back, they are pointless and damaging. The teams of talented and wonderful artists I love you. Your time will come you will be free. You made a wonderful film.

The kind of technical achievement that only comes along once every few years; filled with breathtaking vistas that are all the more impressive when you consider they came out of a computer (sorry nature).  Paired with a decent script adaptation of a classic tale and some truly impressive performances (Idris Elba's Shere Khan is a study in absolute terror) the result is a solid Hollywood blockbuster in its best meaning of the term.  There are a couple of mis-steps; there's no reason for a child raised by British and mid-Atlantic accented wolves to wind up with a broad American twang, and one very ill-advised musical book number pulled from the animated version, but otherwise it's for the most part as good as you'd hope.

Despite some pacing issues, The Jungle Book is a visually resplendent film populated with a top-notch voice cast and filled with equally thrilling, chilling, and touching scenes among its computer-generated--but emotionally-laden characters.
