The Jungle Book captivated me from the moment the camera pulls back from the Disney castle. The characters were engaging, enchanting, and well-created -- this is a remake that truly exceeds its predecessors and will not let you down. I can't wait to buy it as soon as it's released and watch it again and again. I am in love with this movie. One of the best movies I've seen in a long time. The only word I can use to accurately describe how it feels is "captivating." I was captivated, mesmerized, enchanted, and absolutely thrilled with this movie!

Gorgeous to behold and filled with the kind of old-fashioned storytelling that makes one feel like a kid again, Disney's update of The Jungle Book is thoroughly rousing family entertainment. The visuals are incredible considering their creation in a warehouse in LA. The voice performances are all spot on. Neel Sethi is delightfully wide-eyed as Mowgli. Bill Murray is dryly amusing as Baloo, Ben Kingsley wise and stern as Bagheera, Idris Elba menacing and intimidating as Shere Khan and Lupita Nyong'o warm as Raksha. Christopher Walken puts in a fine speaking voice but when the film busts out in a weird and creepy rendition of 'I Wanna Be Like You", Walken can't quite hit the pitches. Scarlet Johansson even gets a wonderfully unnerving scene as Kaa. If there was any proble,s with the film other than the awkward inclusion of two musical numbers, it would be in the CGI which looks gorgeous but can distract at times where it is more noticeable than others. However, the film is consistently enjoyable and the action finale is edge of your seat stuff. Disney's live action reboots continue to surprise. Here's to Beauty and the Beast. Rating: 86

The CGI in this movie was spot on and I enjoyed the 3-D experience. The main character had his opportunities but he carried through the entire film. Overall, I enjoyed the pace and it was beautiful revisiting this world again as an adult.

The Jungle Book gives a fresh new twist to this beloved story, with a more contemporary feel and a more universal appeal. The musical segments are sufficiently dispersed throughout the film, and are woven into the story arch perfectly. Classic favourite 'Bare Necessities' is presented in an ingenious way, being more subtle and stripped back than in earlier versions.

The use of CGI has never looked so smooth in cinema - it is shocking that not a single scene of the feature was filmed in an actual jungle. The casting choices are perfect and the story remains engaging and thrilling throughout; offering a more audacious interpretation of the story than the earlier animated film. 

The Jungle Book is a true credit to director Jon Favreau, and it is plain to see why this film has garnered such widespread acclaim. With ample laughs and numerous scares, this may be one of the best renditions of this age old story to date.

For a film where the cast is almost entirely voice acting, and a jungle made by CGI, The Jungle Book soars to new heights since its Disney premiere in 1967. I'll admit, I was always a fan of the original classic from the 60s, but expected the remake to be just a visually stunning version of the same script. Instead, we are given more background on the main character, Mowgli, as well as a deeper dive into the characters that were left on the back burner by the original animators. Of course, our classic heroes Bagheera and Baloo, as well as the trickster, King Louie, and the villainous Shere Khan, all make an appearance, but we also get to take a look at other characters, most importantly the wolf family that Mowgli is sheltered in since birth. Director Jon Favreau puts a spotlight on the aspect of family, using the wolves as a centerpiece of the film. The choice to highlight these creatures, brought to life brilliantly by Giancarlo Esposito (Breaking Bad) and Lupita Nyong'o (Star Wars: The Force Awakens, 12 Years a Slave), along with an adorable batch of wolf cubs who bring "aww"s and smiles to every moviegoers eyes, is brilliant in putting heart into an otherwise emotion lacking film. Of course, Bill Murray's Baloo is a masterwork and delivers most of the laughs in the film as well, and Ben Kingsley's Bagheera is so perfect that you could listen to him talk for hours and hours, and just love it more and more. Scarlett Johansson has a smaller role than the typical Kaa from the original film, but still delivers a credible vocal performance, bringing the expected chill from her soft voice that captured our attention in Spike Jonze's "Her" in 2013. Now for the BEST and WORST of the vocal performances: starting with the best, Idris Elba as Shere Khan the tiger. His vocal presence is perfect for the villain, and sends chills down the spine, and a sense of fear to the audience in a fantasized story like this. Christopher Walken, on the other hand, falls a bit flat for me. His voice doesn't fit the size and power that his character, King Louie, has, and his song is almost unbearable to listen to. The monkey scene is a tad drawn out and the song doesn't bring the intended excitement to the scene either, given Walken's soft tone and the monkey's lazy stature, and lack of movement. Regardless, the CGI in the film is incredible, and much credit is given to Neel Sethi, the man cub himself. His acting isn't good, but the ability to keep up with a blank set and simply voices is what gives him the impressive edge, and makes the performance bearable. The jungle is beautiful to look at, and the long pans of sunsets, jungle brush, animal herds, and water is breathtaking, and help make this the most beautiful film that Disney has ever made. Similar to Ang Lee's "Life of Pi," the CGI in the animals is almost unrecognizable, and there's really no sense of gimmick or lack of detail. The detail is so precise, from the shed snake skin to Shere Khan's damaged left eye, making the animators and visual effects artists the true champions here. The voice acting is excellent, but what elevates this from the original is the visual masterpiece that we are treated to. This will not leave you disappointed, and is a fun watch for any age or type, packing song, jokes, and lots of heart into a quick 106 minutes of boundless joy.

A visual marvel which and its realistic animation dazzles.  This remake of the 1967 movie borrows little extra from the books but is more intense than before.  Its voice cast generally gives these creatures new life on screen though this movies version of Baloo definitely is not as likable as Phil Harris version.  With some dark moments it might scare some small children and its performance from its child lead leaves something to be desired but despite this I highly recommend giving this visual treat a watch

I honestly had no idea what to expect from a live-action Jungle Book film but I found myself greatly enjoying this film.  I was blown away by the amazing visual effects, pleasantly surprised by the writing and by the story, and really believed in the voice acting and CGI-animated characters as well as the great debut performance by Neel Sethi who brought new, likable, clever, and fun characteristics to Mowgli.  If you were worried about the trend of Disney recreating their animated classics into live-action, fear not.  If they are anything like The Jungle Book, or Cinderella, especially with bringing about the right directors, writers, and team, then we can expect good things from more upcoming films like Beauty and The Beast.

Watching Disney's 'The Jungle Book (2016)' is an exhilarating, terrifying, fun time. Disney and Director, Jon Favreau have taken the two-dimensional, coloring book cut out characters, of the original Jungle Book; Mowgli; the man-cub abandoned in the jungle when he was just a baby and raised by wolves, Bagheera; the devoted, black panther who has vowed to protect the helpless man-cub he found, Baloo; the opportunistic, laid-back bear who grew to love the man-cub, Shere Khan; the menacing vile tiger that vows to kill the man-cub, Kaa; the snake with the hypnotizing stare is intent on making the man-cub her dinner, Raksha; the kind, loving she-wolf; the only mother the man-cub has ever known, and King Louie; the orangutan leader of the monkey army who kidnaps the man-cub, for his enjoyment, and transformed them into larger than life, anthropomorphic, CGI brilliance.  

There is one thing for certain, this is not your grandma's Jungle Book. It's even better. It's edgy, it's exciting, it's spectacular. It is terrifying. Shere Khan (Idris Elba) makes Scar, of 'The Lion King' and Disney's previously most vile feline, look like Bambi. He vows to kill the man-cub just like he killed the man-cub's father. Bagheera (Ben Kingsley) recognizes the man-cub's need of the 'peoples'. It becomes apparent exactly how much the safety of the entire jungle is threatened by Mowgli's mere presence, when Shere Khan (Idris Elba) violently murders Akela (Giancarlo Esposito), the Alpha-wolf that adopted Mowgli. As Raksha (Lupita Nyong'o) bids her man-cub farewell, her love and sheer sorrow pulls the audience into her sense of loss. Bagheera escorts Mowgli on an epic journey out of the jungle to find the 'peoples' village. The journey is fraught with danger. Mowgli, all the while, must stay ahead of Shere Khan. We meet Kaa (Scarlett Johansson), the enormous she-snake that tries to hypnotize Mowgli into becoming her next willing meal; Baloo (Bill Murray) an enormous giant of a bear equipped with claws, teeth, and lack of morals, becomes Mowgli's best friend. We encounter the absolutely terrifying monkey army that delivers Mowgli to King Louie (Christopher Walken), enormous and red. King Louie is the jungle's own mob boss. His appetite for papaya and power is insatiable. Mowgli and his companions are tested by every danger the jungle contains. Mowgli leaves the legend of the man-cub and the jungle behind, to begin life with the 'peoples' but not before his battle to the death, with Shere Khan.  

Usually remakes of classic movies leave the audience let down. Not this remake. 'The Jungle Book (2016)' remains true to the original, complete with the dancing and singing we loved from the original. 'The Jungle Book (2016)' is a work of cinematic genius. Special effects and CGI are mind numbing. However, I would refrain from taking small children to see this movie. The majority of this movie is terrifying. I was at the end of my seat, my hands ready to cover my eyes. Director, Jon Favreau, did a fantastic job keeping with the feeling of original without making it feel dated. The casting is amazing. But it is 12-year old Neel Sethi, cast as Mowgli, that has a brilliant career ahead of himself. His portrayal of Mowgli is warm, engaging, thoughtful, relevant, and most of all believable. The only human of the movie, Sethi's entire performance is alongside a green screen.

Rudyard Kipling would be proud.

I give this movie 4 of 5 'fresh tomatoes', due to how frightening this movie is.

I took my four-year-old grandson to see this. We enjoyed it very much even though we were too late to see it in 3-D. While it failed to deliver the Disney charm of the animated version, it was well done nevertheless and Bill Murray was a major reason why.

rt_summary: Raised by a family of wolves since birth, Mowgli (Neel Sethi) must leave the only home he's ever known when the fearsome tiger Shere Khan (Idris Elba) unleashes his mighty roar. Guided by a no-nonsense panther (Ben Kingsley) and a free-spirited bear (Bill Murray), the young boy meets an array of jungle animals, including a slithery python and a smooth-talking ape. Along the way, Mowgli learns valuable life lessons as his epic journey of self-discovery leads to fun and adventure.
